text: Sip, nosh & learn about eating, drinking & writing about food & wine w/decorated writers, who live la bonne vie, enjoying & covering food & wine at the very highest level! @Salmagundi . Featuring: @MelissaClark @alicefeiring . Moderator: @jessicaseagull Tix: https://tinyurl.com/huv28u43

1/ Simple mushroom pasta: Boil salted water for pasta and cook it; meanwhile, slice about two cups of fresh mushrooms and cook them in a couple of tablespoons of olive oil with some salt and pepper. https://bit.ly/3RTvfLu

2/ When they’re dry, add about half a cup of white wine and some minced garlic; cook until the wine reduces and the garlic mellows. Drain the pasta, reserving some of the cooking water. https://bit.ly/3RTvfLu

Across Ukraine every single day.. @WCKitchen Food fighters are bringing hot meals & essential food kits to families who spent months living in occupation. This week, the team near Kherson met Iryna who stayed in her home under occupation until two of her relatives were killed.

She lives in this village all of her life before she had to flee. My team told me when we brought her a food kit she was so warm & kind… she invited them to her home for coffee. These are the brave Ukrainians we meet every day who WCK will continue to serve. ChefsForUkraine

I once got a -12% on an AP Chem test in high school. Parts were multiple choice, and if you guessed wrong, you received a -.25 value for that question. Somehow this resulted in a statistical paradox of -12%. Teacher rounded up to a 0%.

My teacher was like, “you should study more.” And I was like, “ok but if I get my bench press up 100lbs I’m pretty sure I can get a shot put scholarship and my grades will be meaningless, so I should put effort into that.” And she was like, “… yeah that actually makes sense.”

Learned a lot more about how to be a successful person via sports than I did via school. Not a universal endorsement for sports, nor a universal condemnation of school, but a recognition that there’s a helluvalotta different ways to extract meaning and value from life.

I tried making a list for my Italian college roommates explaining who you do and don’t tip in the US. Do: waiters, bartenders, barbers, cab drivers, tattoo artists Don’t: doctors, yoga instructors, weed dealers, birthday clowns

People bragging about their tipping percentage is weird, too. Order $20 of food and a 25% tip is $5. Order $40 of food and a 20% tip is $8. Server has done the same amount of labor. Ergo, I will start bragging about the virtues of me ordering the $9 sparkling water.

They asked specifically about clowns. Like a birthday clown. I asked if they were preparing to employ a clown. They said no they were just curious. I’m still not sure if you’re supposed to tip clowns tbh. I’m sure they’d appreciate it.

My nutrition plan is such: eat 200g of protein every day, consume other things in relative moderation, and try to keep my body weight between 200-215 lbs but also like don’t stress too much it’s just a number.
I also believe that nobody actually knows how many calories are going into their body! For instance: PAM nonstick spray does not have zero calories. It’s fucking oil. It has as much calories as oil.

Everything is so mind-numbingly complex that it actually becomes very simple. Listen to trusted sources, eat what makes you feel good in the long term, and don’t be afraid of trying new things to see if they make you feel good.

What’s an irrational hatred you and your partner share that let you know they were the one? For instance, my fiancé and I both HATE dinosaurs. Don’t wanna hear facts about them. Don’t wanna see their bones. Screw ‘em.

To be clear, I appreciate and respect people who have made a career out of their interest in dinosaurs. Paleontologists and the like. But I struggle to talk to, and empathize with, casual dino enthusiasts.
